name: Hobnail
description:
This canyon is described in limited detail in Canyons Near Sydney by Rick Jamieson. Help the Australian canyoning community by contributing track notes to ropewiki.com

Most people tend to walk up into the lower section of Hobnail Canyon while doing Bowens Creek South Upper, sure, you get an introduction, and, some pretty bits, but the upper sections are worth doing this as a complete trip.

Approach

Walk along Range fire trail for a short distance from Bells Line until you see the "parked" car on the left, and it is here we headed down the steep hill towards Range Creek. We tended left and met a usually dry feeder rocky creek/chute, that was running, just, making it VERY slippery, a hand-over hand rope assisted with a descent down that chute, to the final short drop into Range Creek.

Descent

A pretty straight forward canyon, creek walking, wades, a swim or two, technically no abseils, through, we did come across one, but found an alternate way down, which was dark and wet. Tends to get choked with flood debris, so be prepared to either tunnel through, or climb over if required.

Exit

The exit is the same as that used for Bowens Creek South Upper, and it is a few hundred metres downstream from where you join onto BCUS.

It has some fixed hand line scrambles, a tunnel climb, then two options for the final ascent, a challenging fixed hand line ascent which we have done a few times up a trickling waterfall, or, further around, a steep scramble. From there, it is a gradual uphill back to Range Hill fire trail and back to Bells Line and your car.

Red tape

Beta sites
